München 85748 Germany Graphical abstract Knowledge of the CO2 interaction with the catalyst material is of great importance in the development of efficient catalysts for the methanation of CO2. In this study, the CO2 adsorption modes on and interaction with Ni-Al catalysts are systematically investigated by coupling FT-IR and CO2-TPD measurements next to pulsed and static CO2 chemisorption. The knowledge that is derived allows for a concise characterization of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalyst by means of CO2-TPD. The strength of this technique in elucidating structure-activity relations of Ni-Al catalysts for CO2 methanation is demonstrated. For the study, catalysts with varying Ni loading are synthesized via co-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation. CO2 adsorption under flow conditions close to room temperature leads to the formation of carbonate species on the catalyst. After elongated exposure of the catalyst to CO2, typically present under static conditions, Ni-CO species are also formed. The density of weak basic sites forming bicarbonate decreases with increasing Ni content for precipitated catalysts, while medium and strong basic sites forming bidentate, monodentate and bridged/”organic”-like species increase. Bicarbonate is the most abundant species on impregnated samples upon CO2 adsorption under flow conditions. Only a minor influence of the Ni loading on the catalyst basicity is observed for the impregnated samples. TPD results also indicate that CO2 adsorption on Ni-Al catalysts is an activated process. A more complete picture of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalysts is obtained when starting TPD measurements at temperatures as low as 218 K. Bicarbonate, bidentate and monodentate carbonate exhibit desorption signals at 325, 416 and 500 K, respectively, while bridged/”organic”-like species show a broad desorption pattern between 550 and 750 K. An additional desorption signal is observed at 260 K. Pulsed CO2 chemisorption reveals that strong adsorption sites are filled first. The uptake of strongly chemisorbed CO2 determined from pulsed adsorption is significantly lower than corresponding values from static chemisorption. Keywords CO2 TPD CO2 interaction Ni catalyst Basic sites Ni-Al mixed oxide IR measurement 1 Introduction The hydrogenation of CO2 was first described by Sabatier and Senderens in 1902 [1], but only recently came back into the focus of research as a promising technology to store energy from renewables [2]. Since its “rediscovery” a broad range of catalytic materials has been investigated for their applicability. Group VIII transition metals like Ni, Rh or Ru supported on SiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2 or CeO2 have been reported to be active for CO2 hydrogenation. A comprehensive overview of catalytic systems studied can be found in recent reviews [3–5]. Supported Ni is probably the most often investigated due to its price and availability. Also Ni-containing mixed oxides gained attention [6–9] in part due to their higher stability as compared to classic metal-support systems [10]. For a good catalytic performance, a high active metal surface area is essential. However, studies have also supplied evidence that the CO2 adsorption capacity as well as the basicity of the catalyst are important [9,11–13]. In order to investigate the interaction of CO2 with catalytic materials and their basicity, infra-red (IR) spectroscopy is widely applied [7,12–20]. While this technique is predestined to elucidate adsorbed CO2 species on the surface, a quantitative analysis of CO2 adsorption is often not straight-forward. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) on the other hand is capable of more easily quantifying CO2 adsorption on different sites. However, it is not possible to determine adsorption modes a priori. Moreover, TPD also allows the study of CO2 interaction at elevated pressures much closer to working conditions, while IR measurements are commonly conducted under vacuum or atmospheric pressure. CO2 adsorption and desorption enthalpies can also be determined by TPD, making it a powerful tool in evaluating the catalyst performance in CO2 conversion reactions. It is reasonable to combine IR and TPR measurements to obtain both qualitative and quantitative information about the CO2 interaction with catalytic materials. However, only some studies so far have applied those techniques for the characterization of CO2 interaction with Ni-containing mixed oxides [7,12,13,19,20]. Moreover, experimental conditions are mostly chosen arbitrarily, although adsorption conditions can have a significant influence on the interaction of the probe gas with the catalyst material, as proven in our previous study [21]. This makes a comparison of experimental results and the attribution of desorption signals to weakly, moderately or strongly adsorbed species difficult. For example, Pan et al. [22] conducted CO2-TPD measurements with activated Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 within the temperature range from 323 to 1173 K. In this range they found three signals and attributed the pattern between 323 and 523 K to weakly adsorbed species, the pattern between 523 and 973 K to species on medium basic sites and the desorption signal at higher temperatures to strongly adsorbed species. In contrast, Muroyama et al. [23] found three distinct desorption signals within the temperature range from 298 and 798 K and attributed the signal between 598 and 798 K to strongly adsorbed species. Mebrahtu et al. [24] correlated performance data of activated Ni-Fe/(Mg, Al)Ox with CO2-TPD pattern, the latter of which, were recorded on catalysts in their calcined state. However, it is known that structural changes of these catalysts take place upon reduction, which might alter their basicity [9]. A systematic investigation of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalysts, to our best knowledge, is lacking. In this study, therefore, we present a detailed study of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalysts by means of FT-IR measurements, temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) as well as pulsed and static CO2 chemisorption. The influence of adsorption modes and conditions on CO2 interaction is evaluated. The influence of the Ni loading, the catalyst synthesis procedure and the catalyst state (calcined or activated) on the basicity are investigated. Adsorbed species are identified and quantified by coupling FT-IR and CO2-TPD measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis and elemental analysis Ni-Al catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation. For co-precipitation, aqueous solutions of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 M, Merck®) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (1 M, Sigma-Aldrich®) were mixed and precipitated at 303 K and a constant pH of 9. An equimolar mixture of 0.5 M NaOH (Merck®) and 0.5 M Na2CO3 (Sigma-Aldrich®) was used as precipitating agent. Details can be found in [6,8]. The Ni loading of the precipitated samples was adjusted by varying the Ni/Al ratio between 1/5, 1/3, 1/2, 1/1, 3/1 and 5/1 (samples donated as PC15, PC13, PC12, PC11, PC31 and PC51 in the following). Also samples just containing Al (PC01) or Ni (PC10), were synthesized in the same way. After precipitation, the precursors were dried at 353 K overnight. Subsequently, the dried precursors, except for PC12, were calcined in flowing air at 723 K for 6 h (5 K min−1). The dried PC12 precursor was calcined at 1173 K in order to obtain NiAl2O4 as reference material. After calcination, the catalyst material was pressed, ground and sieved. The sieve fraction of 150–250 μm was used for measurements. 9 and 17 wt-% Ni/γ-Al2O3 (denoted as IC9 and IC17 in the following) were synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation of γ-Al2O3 from Sasol® (PURALOX SCCa150/200, SBET = 196 m2 g−1 cat, 150–200 μm) with an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1 M, Merck®). After impregnation, the precursors were dried and calcined under the same conditions as the precipitated samples. The actual Ni content was determined via AAS using a Varian® AA280FS and photometry using a Shimadzu® UV-160. 2.2 N2 physisorption and temperature programmed reduction (TPR) N2 physisorption measurements were performed at the boiling point of liquid N2 using a Novatouch from Quantachrome®. For the measurements, roughly 100 mg of calcined catalyst material were placed in the sample cell and degassed under vacuum at 393 K for 3 h prior to analysis. The BET surface area was determined from the adsorption branch of the isotherm within p/p0 = 0.05–0.3. The average pore diameter and volume were calculated assuming spherical pore geometry. TPR measurements and the mass loss during reduction were recorded with a STA thermobalance from Netzsch®. For analysis, 25–50 mg of calcined catalyst were loaded into the crucible and heated in Ar (Q(Ar) = 60 Nml min−1) at 623 K for 1 h (β = 3 K min−1). After cooling down to room temperature, TPR was performed in 5% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 75 Nml min−1 up to a maximum temperature of 1173 K. Product gas analysis was performed with an Omnistar GSD 301 quadrupole mass spectrometer from Pfeiffer®. 2.3 Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) CO2-TPD was studied in greater detail using a setup described elsewhere [21]. All gases were of high purity (5.0 or higher for CO2, 6.0 for He and H2). For analysis, 50–150 mg of catalyst material were fixed in the isothermal zone of the reactor with two plugs of silica wool and a thermocouple was placed in the catalyst bed. For reduction, Ni-Al samples were heated to 753 K in 5% H2 in He at a heating rate of 3 K min−1. The samples were kept at reduction temperature for 5 h. PC10, which does not contain Al, was reduced at 673 K for 2 h (5% H2 in He, β = 3 K min−1). After reduction, the catalysts were purged with He and cooled down to 308 K. Subsequently, the setup was brought to the desired adsorption temperature and CO2 was introduced either in a continuous flow or in a pulsed manner. For adsorption in a continuous mode, a stream of pure CO2 was fed to the reactor for 30–90 min at a flow rate of 50 Nml min−1. Pulsed CO2 adsorption was achieved by injecting 2% CO2 in He into a He stream flowing over the catalyst using of a calibrated sample loop (Q(He) = 13 Nml min−1, V(loop) = 1 ml). After adsorption, the catalyst was flushed with He to remove any weakly adsorbed CO2 and TPD was performed up to 753 K under flowing He (Q(He) = 100 Nml min−1, β = 6 K min−1). Alternatively, CO2 was adsorbed in a three step process. First, CO2 was fed at 308 K for 30 min. Subsequently, the sample was carefully cooled down to 218 K under flowing CO2 where adsorption for another 30 min was conducted. Then, the sample was purged with He and TPD was performed under the same conditions as mentioned before. Adsorption was not conducted at temperatures lower than 218 K to avoid resublimation of CO2. Noisy data was smoothed for presentation. The reactor used in this study was equipped with a shut-off valve at the inlet so that samples could be removed from the setup under inert conditions. 2.4 Ni surface area determination and XRD analysis The specific Ni surface area of activated samples was determined through pulsed H2 adsorption using the same setup as for CO2-TPD experiments. In total, 20–40 pulses of 5% H2 in He (purity 6.0 each) were used. Details can be found in [21]. XRD analysis was performed with a STOE® Stadi P diffractometer operated at 50 kV and 30 mA (Ge(111) monochromator, Cu-Kα radiation, λ = 0.154056 Å). The diffractogram was recorded within 2θ = 5–90° at step size of 0.5° (scanning rate: 0.86° min−1). For analysis, the catalyst material was sealed in glass capillaries with an inner diameter of 0.5 mm. Selected activated catalysts were removed from the setup for CO2-TPD measurements under inert conditions and separated from silica wool in a glovebox prior to analysis. Also here, noisy data was smoothed for presentation. 2.5 FT-IR measurements FT-IR spectra at atmospheric pressure were recorded with a BioRad® FTS 575 C equipped with a high temperature chamber with ZnSe windows. For analysis, selected catalyst samples (150–250 μm) were reduced in the setup for CO2-TPD measurements under the same conditions as mentioned above. After reduction, the catalyst material was removed from the setup and transferred into a glovebox under inert conditions where it was separated from silica wool. The pure catalyst material was pressed into a self-supporting wafer, which was mounted into the spectrometer without being exposed to air. PC10, PC01, PC12 and γ-Al2O3 were not reduced prior to IR measurements but directly pressed into wafers. The wafer and chamber were conditioned by heating to 523 K in He (60 Nml min−1) at a rate of 5 K min−1. Then, the wafer was cooled down to 313 K. For background correction, FT-IR spectra of the clean sample were recorded at various temperatures during the cooling procedure. Subsequently, CO2 was adsorbed for 30 min at 313 K using 6% CO2 in He with a flow rate of 40 Nml min−1. After adsorption, the wafer was purged and TPD up to 523 K was conducted in flowing He (Q(He) = 60 Nml min−1) at a constant heating rate of 5 K min−1. During adsorption, purging and TPD, FT-IR spectra where recorded, from which the background spectra at the corresponding temperature where subtracted in order to remove contributions of the chamber windows and the clean sample to the absorbance. All spectra were recorded within the range from 900 to 4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Alternatively, FT-IR measurements were conducted with a Vertex 70 from Bruker®, equipped with a high temperature chamber with CaF2 windows. For the measurements, 50–100 mg of calcined catalyst material (150–250 μm) were pressed into a self-supporting wafer and reduced under the same conditions as for CO2-TPD. After reduction, the sample was degassed at reduction temperature for 60 min and cooled down to 303 K under He. Subsequently, a spectrum of the clean sample was collected for later background correction. Then, CO2 was adsorbed either in a continuous flow using 6% CO2 in He at a flow rate of 100 Nml min−1 or under static conditions at a reduced pressure of 2.2 mbar. For the latter, the reduced wafer was evacuated and kept at 1×10−5 mbar for 2 h after reduction. After cooling to 303 K, 6% CO2 in He was dosed into the chamber until a constant pressure of 2.2 mbar was achieved. Subsequently, the wafer was evacuated again to 1×10−5 mbar. Also here, measurements were conducted during adsorption and evacuation with the obtained spectra being corrected for contributions of the background. Spectra were recorded within the range of 1100 to 4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Noisy data was also smoothed for presentation in this case. 2.6 Static CO2 chemisorption Static CO2 chemisorption measurements were conducted in a Quantachrome® Autosorb 1C. 100 mg of calcined catalyst material were placed in the sample cell and reduced at 753 K in 5% H2 in N2 for 5 h (β = 3 K min−1). After reduction, the catalyst was evacuated at 753 K for 60 min and subsequently cooled down to room temperature under vacuum. CO2 was fed at 308 K and an adsorption isotherm was recorded with an equilibration time of 10 min. The total amount of CO2 adsorbed and the reversible CO2 uptake was obtained by extrapolating the corresponding adsorption isotherm to zero pressure. The amount of strongly adsorbed CO2 was obtained by subtracting the reversible from the total CO2 uptake. An increase of the equilibrium time has shown to have no influence on the CO2 uptake. The purity was 5.0 for all gases used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Elemental analysis and catalyst characterization Results from elemental analysis and metallic Ni surface area determination are summarized in Table 1 and S.1. XRD analysis, which is discussed in greater detail in section S.1, reveals a takovite-like structure in PC51 and PC31 after precipitation and mixed basic carbonates in Ni-containing precursors. Calcination of these precursors leads to the formation of a crystalline bunsenite and a Ni-Al mixed oxide phase. The structure of these phases depends on the Ni content in the sample. Impregnated samples exhibit a crystalline bunsenite and a γ-Al2O3 phase after calcination independent of the Ni loading. NiAl2O4 is the only crystalline phase in sample PC12 and NiO is observed in sample PC10. These samples, therefore, can be referred to as NiAl2O4 and NiO reference, respectively. Results obtained from N2 physisorption and TPR measurements are discussed in section S.2 and S.3, respectively. 3.2 FT-IR measurements upon CO2 adsorption under flow Results from FT-IR measurements upon CO2 adsorption under flow at room temperature, followed by He purging and TPD are depicted in Fig. 1 and Table 2 . Also the spectra of CO2 adsorption on NiO (PC10) and NiAl2O4 (PC12) are presented for reference purposes in Fig. 2 . Multiple adsorption bands between 900 and 1800 cm−1 are observed, which are typical of carbonate-like species. For γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1A–C), the absorbance bands at 1647 and 1435 cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric OCO stretching mode of bicarbonate, respectively. The corresponding δ(OH) band is observed at 1229 cm−1. Bicarbonates are formed due to the interaction of CO2 with AlIV and/or AlIV-OH sites of weak basicity [25–27]. These bands are formed fast within the first minutes of adsorption and only slightly gain intensity with increasing adsorption time. These observations are in good agreement with results of Wang et al. [25]. The signal centered at 1389 cm−1 can be attributed to the symmetric OCO stretching mode of monodentate carbonate. The corresponding band of the asymmetric OCO stretching mode is observed as a shoulder at 1535 cm−1. The shoulder between 1312 and 1352 cm−1 originates from the symmetric OCO stretching mode of bidentate carbonate. The signal of the corresponding symmetric OCO stretching mode is strongly overlapped by the signal at 1647 cm−1 but can be discerned at 1628 cm−1 upon purging with He (Fig. 1B). Moreover, a broad feature between 1000 and 1200 cm−1 is observed. Purging with He after CO2 adsorption reduces the intensity of signals at wavenumbers higher than 1200 cm−1. The intensity decrease is most pronounced for bicarbonate indicating that those species are weakly bound to the surface, which is in good agreement with literature [25]. The signal intensity of the broad pattern between 1000 and 1200 cm−1 remains unchanged upon He purging, implying that those bands represent strongly bound species, which have been described as bridged/”organic”-like carbonate in literature [14,25]. Upon TPD, bands attributed to bicarbonate are the first to disappear at temperatures higher than 393 K (Fig. 1C). This, again, reflects the weak basic character of adsorption sites forming bicarbonate. Bidentate and monodentate carbonate bands vanish at temperatures higher than 433 K, whereas bridged/”organic”-like species are observed until 514 K. Consequently, bi- and monodentate carbonate are formed on basic sites of medium strength and bridged/”organic”-like species arise from CO2 adsorption on strong basic sites. The shape of the spectrum obtained after CO2 adsorption on PC10 (Fig. 2) agrees well with the one of γ-Al2O3, indicating the formation of carbonates. However, the bands are shifted to lower wavenumbers and a clearly discerned band at 1016 cm−1 is observed. In literature, the absorbance band at 1215 cm−1 is ascribed to bicarbonate [14]. The absorbance bands centered around 1626 and 1385 cm−1 exhibit the same behavior, which strongly indicates that these bands can be attributed to bicarbonate as well. Interestingly, these absorbance bands are established fast within the first minute of adsorption but decrease in intensity with increasing adsorption time, which implies restructuring and rearrangement of the adsorbed carbonate species. An additional signal at 1261 cm−1 is observed. Ueno at al. ascribed this signal, which was observed at 1276 cm−1 in their study, to Ni carboxylate [28]. A corresponding band observed at 1545 cm−1 in literature might not be discerned here due to a strong overlap with the broad signal at 1626 cm−1. The signal positions between 1200 and 1800 cm−1 upon CO2 adsorption on NiAl2O4 (PC12) (Fig. 2) coincide with the band positions in the case of γ-Al2O3, indicating that essentially the same bicarbonate, monodentate carbonate, and bidentate carbonate species are observed. No additional signals pointing at Ni carboxylate formation are detected. In comparison with γ-Al2O3, an additional absorbance band at 1018 cm−1 is obtained which coincides with the signal at 1016 cm−1 in NiO (PC10). Also here, the absorbance bands at wavenumbers below 1200 cm−1 are stable upon He purging and are the last to disappear at temperatures higher than 473 K (Fig. S.4). This indicates that those bands arise form strongly bound species such as bridged/”organic”-like species. The spectra obtained after CO2 adsorption on PC01 (Fig. 1D–F) reveal essentially the same species as for γ-Al2O3. However, the fraction of bidentate carbonate (in this case with an absorbance band between 1318 and 1367 cm−1) is increased, whereas the amount of strongly bound CO2 exhibiting bands below 1200 cm−1 is decreased. CO2 adsorption on IC17 (Fig. 1G–I) leads to the same pattern as for pure γ-Al2O3. The intensity of bands originating from monodentate carbonate increases in comparison to the signal intensity of bicarbonate. The absorbance band of the symmetric O-C-O stretching mode of monodentate carbonate is slightly shifted to a lower wavenumber of 1377 cm−1. However, already intensity changes of strongly overlapping signals can lead to apparent shifts in the signal position. Additionally, a distinct absorbance band is observed at 1070 cm−1, which most likely originates from CO2 adsorbed on strong basic sites, e.g. in a bridged mode, as is does not decrease upon He purging (Fig. 1H) and is stable up to a temperature of 473 K (Fig. 1I). In the pattern obtained after CO2 adsorption for 1 and 5 min, an additional signal at 1256 cm−1 is observed together with a weak shoulder at 1211 cm−1. A comparison with the spectra obtained for pure NiO (Fig. 2) reveals that these bands might originate from carboxylate species and bicarbonate due to CO2 interaction with NiO-like structures. TPR measurements revealed that IC17 is not completely reduced under the chosen reduction conditions (see section S.3). Therefore, NiO-like structures might still be present in the sample, leading to the observed bands. The pattern obtained after CO2 adsorption on PC13 (Fig. 1J–L), the sample which reveals a similar Ni content as sample IC17, coincides with the corresponding spectra of the impregnated sample. Moreover, the band positions in the range between 1200 and 1800 cm−1 do not change with increasing Ni content of the precipitated mixed oxide samples. This indicates that neither the synthesis procedure nor the Ni loading of the Ni-Al systems in this study influence the vibration mode of surface species adsorbed on weak and medium basic sites. With increasing Ni loading of precipitated systems, the density of medium and strong basic sites increases as compared to weak basic sites, which form bicarbonate. In all precipitated samples investigated, the shoulder at 1211 cm−1 is present. The band centered at 1258 cm−1, which is observed in sample IC17 and PC13, is not discerned in sample PC11 (Fig. 1M–O), which might be due to a strong overlap by bands at higher wavenumbers. Also the reducibility increases with higher Ni loading and consequently, the amount of NiO-like structures that form species, which exhibit bands at these wavenumbers, declines. In sample PC11, two distinct bands at 1097 and 1034 cm−1 are observed, whereas one broad band centered between 1070 and 1086 cm−1 is observed on samples of lower Ni loading. This might indicate, that two different strongly adsorbed species are formed on the catalyst PC11. In all samples, bands attributed to bicarbonate significantly decrease upon purging with He. Upon TPD, they are also the first to vanish at temperatures higher than 393 K, followed by bidentate carbonate, monodentate carbonate and strongly bound species, the latter of which exhibit bands at wavenumbers below 1200 cm−1. In the case of PC11, a negative band between 1550 and 1700 cm−1 is observed, which could be attributed to structural changes of the catalyst surface, altering the IR absorption behavior of the wafer. As absorption of the wafer contributes to the background spectra, which are subtracted from each measurement, changes of the wafer absorption behavior become manifest in the corrected spectra. In this context, one might take elimination of surface hydroxyl groups into consideration [26]. Next to a negative band, a new absorbance band is detected at 993 cm−1, which is stable even at temperatures up to 523 K. This again, could be attributed to changes of the catalyst surface properties or to restructuring and transformation of the adsorbed species. Carbonate transformation was observed in literature upon CO2 adsorption and desorption from hydrotalcite-like materials [16]. Further studies are needed to clarify the observed phenomena. 3.3 FT-IR measurements upon CO2 adsorption under static conditions Results from static CO2 adsorption on sample PC11 under static conditions at room temperature and 2.2 mbar leads to additional signals between 1700 and 2100 cm−1 next to absorption bands in the carbonate region (Fig. 3 and Table 3 ). Those bands can be attributed to Ni-CO species formed upon dissociative adsorption of CO2 on metallic Ni. The absorption bands at 2006 and 1894 cm−1 can be ascribed to linearly bound and bridged CO, respectively [20,23,29–32], while the band at 1807 cm−1 most likely originates from CO bound to three Ni atoms [32]. The shoulder between 1800 and 1700 cm−1 might be attributed to an overlap with bands at lower wavenumber. Upon evacuation to 1×10-5mbar (Fig. 3B), no significant decrease of the band intensity is observed for Ni-CO species whereas carbonate absorption bands loose intensity. In contrast to this, no bands related to Ni-CO species are detected upon adsorption under flow conditions, which is in agreement with studies of Abello et al. [7] and Pan et al. [12]. However, dissociation, which is thermodynamically favored as compared to chemisorption on Ni [33], is observed in literature when adsorbing CO2 on Ni-Al catalysts at elevated temperatures [20,23,32]. It is possible that dissociative CO2 adsorption is kinetically hindered at room temperature so that very low residence times, which are typically obtained under flow conditions, do not allow for the formation of Ni-CO species. Activated CO2 dissociation also has been observed on some clean Ni surfaces and reported in literature [34]. At this point, we would like to mention again, that IR measurements under static conditions were conducted with a different setup as compared to measurements, the results of which are depicted in Fig. 1. In order to exclude systematic errors, we also conducted flow experiments in the second setup. Also here, no Ni-CO bands were observed, which further confirms that Ni-CO bands are formed upon static CO2 adsorption at room temperature. No bands related to Ni(CO)4 were observed in our experiments. 3.4 Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 TPD results for catalyst PC11 after CO2 adsorption at 308 K for 30 min are depicted in Fig. 4 . CO2 desorption from weak basic sites exhibits a desorption signal at 364 K, whereas desorption from medium basic sites results in signals centered around 416 and 500 K. In addition, a broad feature between 550 and 750 K is observed, originating from CO2 desorbing from strong basic sites. A comparison of the patterns in Fig. 4 with the FT-IR results in Fig. 1 allows for the assignment of the desorption signals to different species. The desorption signal at 364 K can be attributed to bicarbonate desorbing from weak basic sites. The signal at 416 K originates from bidentate carbonate. The desorption peaks at 500 K and between 550 and 750 K can be ascribed to monodentate carbonate and bridged/”organic”-like species, respectively. The assignment is in very good agreement with results of Wang et al. [25]. At temperatures higher than 550 K next to CO2 also substantial amounts of CO are detected (a quantitative analysis is presented below). FT-IR results show that no Ni-CO species are formed during adsorption under flow conditions at 303 K. Therefore, it is likely that CO is detected due to dissociation of desorbing CO2 at elevated temperatures with oxygen staying on the Ni surface. This is further supported by CO formation upon pulsing of CO2 onto a reduced PC11 sample at 700 K (Fig. S.5). Besides, the Ni surface area does not change upon CO2 exposure at 308 K which is shown by a value of 19.2 m2 gcat −1 before and 19.9 m2 gcat −1 after CO2 adsorption. This additionally proves that, under the chosen conditions, CO2 dissociates on metallic Ni at elevated temperatures but not close to room temperature. When reproducing TPD measurements on the same sample, a decrease of CO2 desorption is observed, indicating a reduction of basic sites. This is in line with results from FT-IR measurements, which also indicated structural changes of the catalyst surface. No structural changes of the catalyst bulk material are observed upon CO2-TPD as revealed by XRD analysis (Fig. S.6). The amount of CO also declines from one TPD experiment to the other. It is likely, that oxygen on the Ni surface, formed during the first TPD run, impedes dissociative CO2 adsorption in the subsequent runs. Upon H2 treatment at 753 K for 30 min (5% H2 in He, β = 3 K min−1), the original state of the catalyst surface is restored. Also the detected amount of CO increases again and reaches its original level. Fig. 5 depicts the influence of adsorption time and temperature on adsorption. Increasing the adsorption time at 308 K slightly enhances adsorption on weak basic sites forming bicarbonate. The amount of monodentate carbonate and the density of strong basic sites is reduced, in compliance with results depicted in Fig. 4, since curve (a) and curve (b) were recorded successively. Adsorption at 373 K (curve (c) and (d)) increases desorption from weak and medium basic sites, indicating that adsorption on Ni-Al catalysts is an activated process. An increase of adsorption time at 373 K slightly further improves adsorption on medium basic sites (not indicated in Fig. 5). Species on medium basic sites are flushed from the catalyst surface at 373 K, which explains the lower signal intensity of curve (d) as compared to curve (c). CO2 adsorption in a three step process including adsorption at 308 as well as 218 K leads to an intensity increase of the signals attributed to weak and medium basic sites (curve (e)). The onset of an additional desorption signal is observed around 260 K. The signal attributed to bicarbonate is shifted to lower temperatures by approximately 10 K and becomes more symmetrical. This indicates that weak basic sites are only partially occupied at 308 K and that part of the adsorbed CO2 is removed when flushing prior to TPD. This is in line with FT-IR results depicted in Fig. 1. The influence of the Ni loading and the synthesis procedure on CO2 desorption is depicted in Fig. 6 . Sample PC01 exhibits a board desorption signal between 225 and 375 K, indicating a high density of weak basic sites, as well as a broad shoulder at higher temperatures. In comparison, the density of weak basic sites in the Ni-containing sample PC15 is decreased. It further declines with increasing Ni loading of the precipitated samples, whereas the amount of bidentate and monodentate carbonate as well as strongly adsorbed species rises. No significant differences in basicity are observed between PC31 and PC51. However, clear distinguishable signals related to bidentate, monodentate and strongly bound species cannot be detected for sample PC15 and PC13. This might be attributed to the strong desorption signal originating from bicarbonate overlapping smaller peaks as evident by the shoulder at higher temperatures. No signal shifts are observed, which means that the same kind of adsorbed CO2 species are observed in each catalyst. These observations are also in line with FT-IR results depicted in Fig. 1. When varying the Ni loading of impregnated systems, no significant change of the CO2 adsorption behavior is observed. The obtained TPD patterns coincide with the one of γ-Al2O3 with a slightly increased CO2 desorption from medium and strong basic sites. However, also here, the strong desorption signal attributed to bicarbonate might superimpose less intense peaks at higher temperatures. Comparing the pattern of sample PC01 and γ-Al2O3 reveals that the density of weak basic sites is significantly higher in sample PC01. Results from TPD after pulsed CO2 adsorption are depicted in Fig. 7 . Adsorption of limited CO2 amounts by varying the number of pulses reveals that strong adsorption sites are occupied first and subsequently weaker sites are filled. Once CO2 pulses break through and reach a constant intensity, the subsequent TPD pattern remains constant (pulsed adsorption prior to curve (d) and (e) in Fig. 7A). The signal intensity declines from curve (a) to (e), which again might originate from structural changes of the catalyst surface upon TPD, as mentioned earlier, since the measurements were conducted sequentially on the same catalyst sample. This also explains the higher intensity of the desorption signals after pulsed adsorption on a fresh catalyst sample (Fig. 7B). The desorption signal intensity after adsorption of 40 pulses at a dosing temperature of 308 K is significantly lower as compared to the TPD pattern obtained after CO2 adsorption at 308 K using a continuous gas stream (Fig. 7B). The TPD pattern obtained after pulsed adsorption in Fig. 8 reveals that mostly weak basic sites are present on calcined PC11. Upon reduction, medium and strong basic sites are formed, while the weak basic site density is reduced. It is well known, that structural changes take place during the reduction of precipitated catalysts [6–8 10,35], which very likely changes the basicity. Next to structural changes, surface hydroxyl groups, which are essential for the formation of bicarbonate, are eliminated during reduction [36], decreasing the density of weak basic sites. These results also point out the importance of characterizing catalyst materials in their active state. Results of TPD measurements subsequent to CO2 adsorption on γ-Al2O3 before and after reduction are depicted in Fig. S.7. Heating in H2 leads to a significant reduction of weak basic sites, most likely due to elimination of surface hydroxyl groups as indicated by TPR results (section S.3). No significant changes are observed with regard to the density of medium and strong basic sites. A quantitative analysis of the pulsed experiments in Fig. 7 reveals that only 40–55% of the CO2 adsorbed on the reduced catalyst sample desorb during TPD (Table 4 ). As evident from FT-IR measurements, part of the CO2 adsorbed is flushed from the catalyst surface during purging prior to TPD. Moreover, the maximum temperature of 753 K might not be high enough to completely desorb strongly adsorbed CO2 species, which is shown by TPD coupled with FT-IR measurements in Fig. 1O. Furthermore, a part of the CO2 desorbing is converted to CO at temperatures higher than 550 K, as mentioned earlier and shown in Fig. 4 and 7B. This further explains the observed discrepancy between adsorbed and desorbed CO2. Correcting the CO signal in Fig. 7B for CO2 fragmentation allowed for the quantification of the detected CO. A total CO amount of 12.0 μmol g−1 cat is released, which is 11.4% of the CO2 retained by the catalyst upon pulsing. Results from static CO2 chemisorption and a comparison with pulsed CO2 adsorption and TPD are summarized in Table 1. In the case of γ-Al2O3, the adsorbed CO2 amount upon pulsing is only 28% of the irreversible CO2 uptake calculated from static measurements. As indicated in Fig. 6 γ-Al2O3 mostly exhibits weak basic sites, which are only partially occupied at low CO2 partial pressures and residence times, typically present in pulsed experiments. Static conditions, in contrast, allow for more sites to be filled, which explains the higher value obtained. The same discrepancy is observed for PC01 where 22% of the irreversible CO2 uptake determined from static chemisorption are adsorbed upon CO2 pulsing. Also for Ni-containing samples, deviations between static and pulsed experiments are observed. However, the deviations decrease with increasing Ni loading. This is in line with the density increase of medium and strong basic sites at higher Ni content (Fig. 6), on which the adsorption is less strongly influenced by the CO2 partial pressure. Also the formation of Ni-CO species under static conditions (Fig. 3) has to be taken into consideration as an additional reason for the observed deviations. As mentioned earlier, dissociative CO2 adsorption on metallic Ni is likely to be kinetically hindered close to room temperature. Low residence times, typically obtained in pulsed experiments, therefore, impede dissociation. In contrast, long equilibration times in static chemisorption measurements allow for Ni-CO formation. The total CO2 adsorption capacity of Ni-containing samples, determined from static chemisorption, decreases with increasing Ni content. Contrary to this, the irreversible CO2 uptake and the amount of adsorbed CO2 determined from pulsed experiments and TPD initially decreases for precipitated samples with rising Ni content and reaches a minimum at a Ni loading between 22.5 and 38.1 wt-%. At higher loadings, the adsorbed amount of CO2 rises again. The contradictory trend of total and reversible CO2 uptake is in agreement with the increasing density of weak basic sites with rising Al content. The initial decrease from sample PC15 to PC13, which exhibit similar densities of medium basic sites, could be attributed to the significantly higher weak basic site density of sample PC15 (Fig. 6A). More CO2 can be adsorbed on those sites even upon evacuation in the case of PC15. The irreversible CO2 uptake slightly decreases with increasing Ni loading for the impregnated samples. Pulsing of CO2 onto unsupported metallic Ni (reduced PC10) revealed an insignificant CO2 uptake. This again supports that CO2 does not dissociate on metallic Ni at room temperature under transient conditions. 4 Catalyst performance in CO2 methanation Recently, we investigated the catalytic performance as well as the deactivation behavior of catalyst PC31, PC11, PC13 and IC17 in CO2 methanation in great detail [10]. The activity per Ni surface area (specific activity) was shown to vary for the samples investigated, as indicated in Fig. 9 . This suggests structure sensitivity as well as additional factors which influence the activity. In this context, the CO2 adsorption capacity and the basicity of the catalyst material was reported to be important [12,13,37]. As shown in Fig. 6, and as discussed in our previous study [10], the density of medium basic sites forming monodentate formate rises with increasing Ni loading of precipitated samples. Pan et al. [12] proposed that medium basic sites forming monodentate formate species promote CO2 methanation as monodentate formate is hydrogenated faster than other formate species. This is in line with a higher specific activity of sample PC31 as compared to samples of a lower Ni content. Moreover, the results nicely demonstrate the strength of CO2-TPD measurements in evaluating and elucidating structure-activity relations. 5 Conclusion Adsorption modes and the interaction of CO2 with co-precipitated and impregnated Ni-Al catalysts were elucidated using FT-IR spectroscopy, CO2-TPD as well as pulsed and static CO2 chemisorption. Adsorption close to room temperature under flow conditions leads to the formation of four different species on the surface, namely bicarbonates (adsorbed on weak basic sites), bidentate carbonates, monodentate carbonates (adsorbed on medium basic sites) and bridged/”organic”-like species (adsorbed on strong basic sites). The density of medium and strong basic sites increases with increasing Ni loading, whereas the amount of bicarbonate decreases. Bicarbonate is the most abundant species on impregnated samples and γ-Al2O3. In the subsequent TPD run, bidentate, monodentate and bridged/”organic”-like species exhibit a desorption signal at 416 and 500 K as well as a broad desorption pattern between 550 and 750 K, respectively. An additional CO signal at temperatures higher than 550 K originates from dissociation of desorbing CO2. Close to room temperature, dissociative CO2 adsorption on Ni is not observed under flow conditions, but is observed under static conditions forming Ni-CO species. Variation of the adsorption time and temperature implies that CO2 adsorption on Ni-Al-catalysts is an activated process. Adsorption of CO2 at temperatures as low as 218 K leads to a more complete adsorption on weak basic sites, forming bicarbonate with a corresponding desorption signal at 325 K and an additional desorption signal at 260 K. Pulsed CO2 adsorption reveals that strong adsorption sites are filled first. The amount of adsorbed CO2 is significantly lower than under flow or static conditions, which demonstrates that the experimental design has a strong influence on the CO2 interaction and adsorption modes on Ni-Al catalysts. The results provide the necessary knowledge to concisely characterize the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalyst by means of CO2-TPD. The strength of this technique in elucidating structure-activity relations of Ni-Al catalysts in CO2 methanation was shown. coredata.dc:description: Knowledge of the CO2 interaction with the catalyst material is of great importance in the development of efficient catalysts for the methanation of CO2. In this study, the CO2 adsorption modes on and interaction with Ni-Al catalysts are systematically investigated by coupling FT-IR and CO2-TPD measurements next to pulsed and static CO2 chemisorption. The knowledge that is derived allows for a concise characterization of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalyst by means of CO2-TPD. The strength of this technique in elucidating structure-activity relations of Ni-Al catalysts for CO2 methanation is demonstrated. For the study, catalysts with varying Ni loading are synthesized via co-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation. CO2 adsorption under flow conditions close to room temperature leads to the formation of carbonate species on the catalyst. After elongated exposure of the catalyst to CO2, typically present under static conditions, Ni-CO species are also formed. The density of weak basic sites forming bicarbonate decreases with increasing Ni content for precipitated catalysts, while medium and strong basic sites forming bidentate, monodentate and bridged/”organic”-like species increase. Bicarbonate is the most abundant species on impregnated samples upon CO2 adsorption under flow conditions. Only a minor influence of the Ni loading on the catalyst basicity is observed for the impregnated samples. TPD results also indicate that CO2 adsorption on Ni-Al catalysts is an activated process. A more complete picture of the CO2 interaction with Ni-Al catalysts is obtained when starting TPD measurements at temperatures as low as 218 K. Bicarbonate, bidentate and monodentate carbonate exhibit desorption signals at 325, 416 and 500 K, respectively, while bridged/”organic”-like species show a broad desorption pattern between 550 and 750 K. An additional desorption signal is observed at 260 K. Pulsed CO2 chemisorption reveals that strong adsorption sites are filled first. The uptake of strongly chemisorbed CO2 determined from pulsed adsorption is significantly lower than corresponding values from static chemisorption.
coredata.dc:title: On the interaction of CO2 with Ni-Al catalysts
